raw_text:
Thanou bullish over drugs hearing
 
 Katerina Thanou is confident she and fellow sprinter Kostas Kenteris will not be punished for missing drugs tests before the Athens Olympics.
 
 The Greek pair appeared at a hearing on Saturday which will determine whether their provisional bans from athletics' ruling body the IAAF should stand. "After five months we finally had the chance to give explanations. I am confident and optimistic," said Thanou. "We presented new evidence to the committee that they were not aware of."
 
 The athletes' lawyer Grigoris Ioanidis said he believed the independent disciplinary committee set up by the Greek Athletics Federation (SEGAS) would find them innocent. "We are almost certain that the charges will be dropped," said Ioanidis.
 
 "We believe that we have presented [a case] that the charges are unreasonable." Thanou, the 2000 Olympic women's 100m silver medallist, and Sydney 200m champion Kenteris were suspended by the IAAF for missing three drugs tests. The third was supposed to take place on the eve of the Athens Games last August, but the pair could not be found in the athletes' village. They were later taken to hospital after claiming to have been involved in a motorcycle accident. Thanou's coach Christos Tzekos was also suspended by the IAAF. "We were asked [by the disciplinary committee] all kinds of questions about the night of 12 August," said Tzekos. "We did not leave any gaps. As far as I am concerned there is no such issue [of refusing to be tested], and I am very optimistic." Tzekos, Thanou and Kenteris, who have all denied the charges, can expect a decision within a month. "Deliberations will start after some additional documents are brought in by Thursday," said committee chairman Kostas Panagopoulos. "I estimate that the final ruling will be issued by the end of February."
llama3.2:1b: Katerina Thanou and fellow sprinter Kostas Kenteris appeared at a hearing to contest their provisional bans from athletics due to missing three drugs tests. They presented new evidence to dispute charges, with Ioanidis claiming they are "almost certain" the charges will be dropped.
llama3.2:3b: Katerina Thanou and Kostas Kenteris confident they won't be punished for missing drugs tests, presenting new evidence to a Greek disciplinary committee that they claim the charges are unreasonable.
gemma2:2b: Katerina Thanou and Kostas Kenteris, Greek athletes who missed drug tests before the 2004 Olympics, had a hearing where they presented new evidence to support their innocence. Their lawyer believes charges against them will be dropped. The pair have denied the accusations and their coach says he has not seen any evidence of refusal to be tested. A final decision on their provisional bans is expected within a month.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Thanou and her teammate Kenteris appear to have cleared their IAAF drug test cases, with a hearing set for Saturday. The pair were suspended from athletics as a result of missing three drugs tests scheduled for August 12 in Athens.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Athletes Katerina Thanou and Kostas Kenteris, suspended for missing drug tests before the Athens Olympics, appear at a hearing where they present new evidence to avoid penalties. The athletes' lawyer believes the independent committee set up by Greek Athletics Federation will find them innocent. They are expected to receive a decision within a month.
qwen2.5:3b: Katerina Thanou and Kostas Kenteris are confident they won't face punishment for missing drugs tests prior to Athens Olympics due to a motorcycle accident. A hearing concluded with evidence presented suggesting ignorance, backed by their lawyer who believes charges will be dropped. The independent Greek Athletics Federation committee set up for the hearings is expected to rule within a month based on additional documents submitted by Thursday.

<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about Katerina Thanou and Kostas Kenteris's case before the Greek Olympics. Let me read through it carefully.

So, the main points are: Thanou is confident she won't get punished for missing drug tests. She's with Kenteris in a hearing where they face suspension if they don't meet certain criteria. They were suspended for three times, including the August 12th test, which was supposed to be before the Games.

I should note that their suspended status means they could face discipline issues after the games. The Greek Athletics Federation's disciplinary committee is reviewing their case. Thanou and Kenteris are using expert testimony; I think they've got new evidence showing they were unaware of drug tests on the day. Their lawyer, Ioanidis, says they're innocent.

Christos Tzekos was also suspended for failing to report that night. He's part of the team, which is a bit concerning. They have a month until they can decide their case, so I should mention that too.

I need to make sure I capture all key details without adding extra information. Keep it concise and only include the main points:Thanou's optimism, their suspended status for three drug tests including August 12th, their expert testimony about not knowing the tests, Ioanidis' confidence in their innocence, Tzekos's suspension, and the expected outcome of a decision within a month.

Alright, I think that covers everything. Time to put it all together into a coherent summary.
</think>

Katerina Thanou is confident she and Kostas Kenteris won't face discipline for missing drug tests before the Athens Olympics. They will be suspended by the Greek Athletics Federation for three test absences, including August 12th. Their expert testimony shows they were unaware of the tests on that night. Ioanidis, their lawyer, believes them innocent. Christos Tzekos was also suspended. The hearing determines if they can retain their positions. A decision is expected within a month, starting after additional documents are brought in by Thursday and ending by February.
tinyllama:1.1b: Katerinia Thanou, along with her fellow sprinter Kostas Kenteriis, was cleared of drug violations by a hearing organized by the IAAF's independent disciplinary committee. The pair had missed three drug tests before the Athens Olympics last August, but were eventually taken to hospital after making claims about being involved in a motorcycle accident. Thanou's coach, Christos Tzekos, was also suspended from athletics by the IAAF. As far as Thanou and Kenteriis are concerned, there is no such issue of refusing to be tested, and they can expect a decision within a month after some additional documents are received. The final ruiling will likely be issued before the end of February.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Athens, Greece - Katerina Thanou, a sprinter from Greece, and Kostas Kenteris, another sprinter also from Greece, have reached a compromise in their drug testing case. The pair appeared at an important hearing on Saturday where they were finally given the chance to give explanations for missing the drugs tests before Athens Olympics. 

Following five months of waiting, both Thanou and Kenteris shared that they felt confident in presenting new evidence during this hearing. This information is expected to play a crucial role in determining whether their provisional bans from the IAAF should stand. Following a thorough review of the charges, the independent disciplinary committee will then determine if the pair deserve to be pardoned or not.

Thanou, a 2000 Olympic women's 100m silver medallist and Sydney 200m champion Kenteris were initially suspended by the IAAF for missing three drugs tests. The third test was supposed to take place on the eve of the Athens Games last August, but the pair could not be found in the athletes' village. As a result, they were later taken to the hospital after claiming that they had been involved in a motorcycle accident.

Tzekos, Thanou's coach, was also suspended by the IAAF due to his involvement in this case. 

Thanou and Kenteris can expect a decision within a month regarding their legal issues. In the meantime, they have been allowed the opportunity to present new evidence or answer any additional questions from the disciplinary committee. If all parties are deemed innocent of the charges, they should not face any further sanctions but will instead be allowed to compete in other events at the future Olympic Games without facing further penalties.

After five months, they presented new evidence to the committee which they believed would prove they were not aware of the missed tests. Their lawyer is confident that the charges will be dropped by the independent disciplinary committee set up by the Greek Athletics Federation (SEGAS). Their coach also denied any issues with the testing and remains optimistic about the outcome. The final ruling should be issued within a month.

The athletes' lawyer believes they will be found innocent, and the disciplinary committee set up by the Greek Athletics Federation (SEGAS) is almost certain to find them innocent too.
